text: Hello. Hello, sorry we lost you for a second there. Technology, welcome, thank you. So we're to present our annual report for the 2019-2020 Waipā Community Facilities Trust annual report. So, we're up about 13,000 on the previous year.  projected at a visited number of two hundred and fifty three thousand around there, which would have been really good in a record for us. Next slide, one's just to the polls. Down again, we've got a record of about two hundred and fifty three thousand. We've got a record of about two hundred and fifty three thousand.  Down to almost 19,000 visits or 16.8 percent, almost 17 percent. We had a number of bookings in March that cancelled due to school swimming sports. We had a number of them cancelled with the high numbers and obviously the terms going in and school holidays were affected. Next page. If we look at pre-COVID, we're right on track there.  heading into our busy months in March and in school holidays. So, we're still up a little bit on the previous year, which was our busiest year ever. But that is what it is due to COVID. Next slide. The stadium numbers. We're down about 10,000 visits on last year.  We were just kicking into our winter season, which is normally, historically, the busiest terms of the year, the six months busier in the winter codes. And once we went into lockdown, Level 3 closure and then Level 2 was pretty much only high level sport was allowed. Obviously, the magic deal. So, the visitors were down. Pre-COVID on the next slide, which is February, we're up about 2,300  Visits were 10% and then these were the 10 significant bookings that we lost, not including our general mini ball and basketball netball, but some significant tournaments that we lost due to COVID, which is a bit disappointing. Next page, next slide. This is how our gym was tracking, or Club Waipā. We were pretty much on par. We were tracking really well.  quite a bit ahead of the game. So, we're almost on par with last year. Membership dropped significantly. We lost about 107 members due to COVID. So, to get them back, it's been a bit of effort coming in with the team. And the next slide, and that's how we were tracking. So, we're up almost 7,000 visits on the next slide, or 20%. So,  Because we were so far ahead, it didn't affect the overall of the gym too much. We were almost on par. But the group fitness was up and gym membership was up. The team were working really hard on that. So, you know, it's just things that happen. Next slide.  We were given $20,000 in grant funding from Water Safety New Zealand to deliver to schools for the water safety and boat safety. So, we were given $20,000 in grant funding from Water Safety New Zealand to deliver to schools for the water safety and boat safety. We were given $20,000 in grant funding from Water Safety New Zealand to deliver to schools for the water safety and boat safety.  and learn to swim program, which was going really well. Then obviously, once again, COVID hit and had a bit of problem. So, we're still above the previous year at that stage for the total year, and that was before COVID hit. So, we're well on track to break numbers. Next slide. And as you can see, that's how we were tracking pre-COVID.  So, we're quite proud of that, especially the swimming lessons for the schools was going really well. The next one is the big slide, sorry. This is the big impact. We had 268 bookings cancelled in three months, which was about 11,700 lost revenue and projected of about 58,000 visits lost. And in this current year,  when I wrote this presentation, we had 168 bookings cancelled due to the second wave and we're getting cancellations as we speak, especially with Auckland have been in lockdown three. And so some of those competitors can't leave. So they've been cancelling and keeping the hygiene and the standards. We've got gym carnivals that we can't host because they just can't maintain the hygiene levels that are required and wiping down after use and  mats are pretty hard if they're not plastic and things like that so it's probably going to affect us for a while going forward and hopefully we get back to some normality if we get lifted to level one. Health and safety next slide. So generally overall we were a doubt on all last year which is a good thing except for our contaminations  While they've come down significantly over our history of being there, this year we seem to have a number of vomits more than our code browns. So, we don't know the reason for that, but we were on ballpark from last year. Previous years, we obviously dropped significantly with our new food policy and tried to stay on top of it.  But overall, most of them have dropped. Had a few trespass from last year. Seven lot of incidents with little kids or kids not behaving. Poor water quality. Next slide, sorry. Tracking quite well, you can see we're right above the 85. Average is 94. So we're tracking well above and there's a gap  obviously April, May and June. The good thing about COVID for us was we got a chance to do our maintenance period and do a really good clean. We did a lot of tiling and all our expansion joints in our pools, which had been, hadn't been done for a while. So that closure kind of helped us out getting on top of that, which was really good. Feedback.  generally on par. We had more compliments last year. I don't think COVID's helped us any.  with that and then as restrictions are still in place I think generally people's patience you know they want things to go back to normality and trying to keep restrictions on is tough to meet their needs in some aspects but generally pretty good and down on the stuff that really matters but disappointing to lose those compliments I guess not as good.  Next page, please. Capital renewals. So, ASB Stadium, the grandstand that everyone sits in, we've got new motors or drivers to do that. There was a significant cost around the 50k mark when we got all some new pumps for some of the pools.  and we upgraded the trust, invested in the new reception. If anyone's been there lately, you'll see a nice, more welcoming reception and more inviting. And we got new lane ropes and we also did a full renovation of our sauna. So, ripped it all out, new wood, a new heating unit and the heating unit's actually got a water feed to it now. So, one of our  issues we had before was because it's a really dry place and there was no moisture the wood would actually get really brittle and so become a fire hazard over the 20 years that it's been opened and so the new water feed leaves a little bit of moisture in the air that keeps the wood damp so hopefully with us being able to on a cycle roster we'll be able to maintain and keep that going so that seems to have good feedback even though it's closed under level two.  This is and I have to stipulate that these have not been fully audited, but virtually how we're tracking is of zero. So, the funding that we received for between the two years, obviously, the last quarter with covid, we didn't receive as much funding, which is obviously quite understandable.  We had capital renewal funding and then our funding, another trade, and then you can see the government wage subsidy that we received, which was a real help. So, overall income is down and expenditure was down as well. So, our difference was about one hundred and fifty one thousand that we made a deficit before tax or surplus, sorry, surplus before tax.  Okay.

text: Yeah, through Madam Chair, when we got the new flooring done, it was such good flooring that a lot of the body fats would stick on top. And our previous way of cleaning it  and the old elbow and scrubbing brush and the hose didn't cut it. So we purchased  some machines at significant cost that would be scrubbed and do it. So, we have regular cleaning on the flooring with the machines and that's really made a big difference on the flooring. So, over the past year or so, we've been tracking the slip strips and falls due to that. Not from people running, we do running as well, but just normal walking where it was slippery, how other machines are going. So,  we'll be definitely getting those type of machines for the new Cambridge pool as well, sort of thing. So it's the machines that really help. They can lift the dirt. They've got big scrubbing brushes and walk behind and scoops the water up and the dirt up as you go. No, that's really great to hear.

text: I'm not aware if there being any other questions from the  Congratulations for the lack of damage, I suppose, in terms of the users of the facilities.
speaker: susanoregan

text: But the Level 2 restrictions, that 100 people restriction, is that over the whole facility or are you able to have 100 in the pool and 100 in the gym and 100 in the event centre?
speaker: susanoregan

text: So, when we originally heard it, we were told that if we could separate areas and have separate changing rooms and separate entry and exit points, we could have 100 each side. Then we went to our industry meetings and I asked the question, was this true if we could isolate those areas? And they said, no, if it's one centre, it's 100 across the centre.  Yesterday I spoke to somebody from Auckland who came down in our industry and they said they've been separating 100 either side. So we've got to take into account our partners like the cafe. We want them to operate as well. So, you know, and they've got an allocation of about 20. We put 40 in the pool with any one stage.  and that's including the swimmers and parents, but we try to restrict a lot of the parents. So, currently, the swimming lessons are you come and drop your kid in Simon or scan in your code, you wait in your car, the kid gets done, and then we escort the kids to their parents.  trying to reduce those numbers. Once they start bringing siblings and things, we restrict it. We've got no group fitness classes running at the moment. We are re-looking at that, though, to see if we can reduce the class size and spread them out. And then we've got the gym at any one stage and the stadium. So, 100 people comes up pretty quick.  It doesn't take long, especially at peak times. So it's trying to balance that out and be fair to everyone. If we got confirmation we could put 100 either side, that helps us out a lot. But we still got to try and keep the social distancing. And if we have too many people, it's so difficult to manage and then wipe down. You think of all the sports equipment, netball goals, basketballs,  seating, flooring between use, very difficult and time consuming for staff to maintain. So, restricting it is what we've done to be able to maintain some normality in service.
speaker: Unknown

text: We don't want to be ground zero for my part.
speaker: mervandmatt

text: We don't want you to be either. OK, thanks for that.

text: We review our fees and charges every year.  We've just bought a brand new inflatable for the kids that we haven't been able to put up for anybody due to our restrictions. What we try to do is give them bang for buck. So we know some families do struggle at times, so we try and give it for an hour  on the hydra slide and then another hour on the inflatable. We try to make it family friendly. We obviously want to make money and do well out of it, but we also want to get a balance that people want to come and have fun. So we spent some significant money in the maintenance period on the hydra slide, doing all the upgrades that have been begging for a while. So yeah, that's working really well at the moment and can't wait till the new inflatable goes up and see how the kids like it.

text: Great. So now moving on to our next agenda item, which is the Waikato Arts Navigator Report to the Waipā District Council. I believe Debbie, you'd like to introduce our guests this evening. Well, this afternoon rather than morning. Gosh, I'm half asleep. Welcome gentlemen, take away Debbie.
speaker: susanoregan

text: Yeah, so I'd just like to introduce Dez Ratima and Jeremy Mail from Creative Wakato. You might recall that you met Jeremy before at your council induction. So great to have you here, guys. So they're just here to talk to us today about the Wakato Arts Navigator, which we partially funded for stage one. So yeah, take it away, team.
speaker: waipadistrictcouncil

text: I'm good everyone. I'll just do this awkward screen sharing thing so we can see the image and hope that it all does what it's supposed to do. Hopefully we can see that.  So hello, everyone. Dr. Jeremy Maile here on behalf of Creative Waikato, the arts development organisation for the Waikato region, and I'm joined by my colleague, Des. Creative Waikato, for those who are unfamiliar, operates independently across the Waikato region to provide strategic direction and support for sustainable arts, culture and heritage development.  We work with funders, councils, artists and arts organisations to work collaboratively to ensure that the Waikato prospers with diverse and transformative creative activity. We're the navigators who lead the elevation of our region and collaborate to provide opportunities for cultural well-being.  Let me start by saying that I believe the arts are a vital aspect of the lives of individuals in their communities. Arts and culture can illuminate our inner lives and enrich our emotional world. The arts help us to define and express ourselves as well as to engage with each other in our communities. They are powerful levers for promoting positive social change.  The arts function as the conscience of our society. They show us that we make the world rather than simply inherit it. I've been fortunate myself to be actively involved in music, theater, and various other art forms for the majority of my life. Early on as a participatory activity through various music lessons, school and community drama groups, and watching a range of performances. And now more recently as a creator and enabler of various arts experiences, as well as in this role as an advocate for the arts as an essential service.  The arts are a coping mechanism for humanity and they are central to my daily life. One of the primary reasons we make both public and private investments in the arts is for the inherent value of culture. The arts can be life enhancing and entertaining whilst also helping us to define our own identities. They have social and educational benefits as well as various economic ones.  Art and creativity are fundamental to building a healthier society, and this view is widely supported. Here in Aotearoa, New Zealand, research from Creative New Zealand shows that a majority of people believe that the arts help improve society. They say that the arts are good for you, and the evidence states that arts contributes positively to our economy as well as our society. And it is through continued support and investment that many of our young people and emerging artists are able to get their start in this vital field.  Creativity can encourage civic engagement, build resiliency, and contribute to quality of life. More and more studies are highlighting the positive outcomes that art and creativity can have on community and well-being, and it is exciting for me as someone who's involved in the community.  to see various artists and arts groups creating opportunities for people to engage with arts on all levels and that there continues to be support for them from people who recognize that the value of art is well beyond the price tag and that engagement with art and art making processes is vital. Arts engagement offers various social benefits including being part of the treatment for mental health as well as encouraging self-confidence and self-esteem.  As part of the COVID response, we've seen an upsurge in creativity and engagement in the arts. Arts has served as a coping mechanism, a tool to come to terms with our situation, to find solace, to find connection, to find peace. Art is a powerful and transformative element that should be at the core of any recovery work, as well as a fundamental part of society.  Arts engagement has shown to increase teenagers' capacity to communicate and to learn, to relate to each other and to tolerate others, as well as making them more likely to vote. Increasingly, such benefits are presented not as happy byproducts of artistic activity, but as part of its very essence.  So what is the impact of access and investment in the arts in a community? There are countless benefits. The arts increase people's capacity for life, they enrich people's experiences, and they provide powerful applications outside of the artistic experience. Art testifies to the power of the human imagination.  the unique capacity we have to dream. Art tempts us to move beyond our perceived boundaries and limitations to explore a curious and creative new world of possibilities. And I'm convinced that if we have more people engaging with art, the world will continue to be a better place.  But in order for art in the community to thrive, it needs support. The investment you can make as a council can enable a broad range of things. And this investment means having spaces to present work, having people to help make work, having access to materials and technology, to craft work, and having a range of audiences in your own district.  to engage with this work. All of these things are vital to help keep a functioning and beneficial artistic culture alive. Through the arts, we're reminded of what more there is left to do in the world. So why are we here?  We're collectively dealing with a unique and traumatic period of unexpected change. We're in a time of recovery, and we need to take this moment to explore what opportunities are emerging and how we can activate them. What we're talking about is a continuation of the Waikato Arts Navigator. This is a framework developed by Creative Waikato that is available to all councils in the Waikato region. Its goal is to build a collective vision for arts and creative outcomes for all our communities.  The ultimate objective of the Waikato Arts Navigator is to have all councils in the region making decisions for arts at development with the following outcomes in mind. Creative prosperity, creative experiences, creative well-being, and creative excellence.  We know that the Navigator aligns itself with the long-term plan, and we find that arts-based methodologies can support the vision that you have as a council. We see that the arts and culture are part of the bigger societal ecosystem, one that brings cultural practices into spaces and places and develops outputs which lead to positive outcomes and clear benefits for community. You can see a map of that in your report.  We also know that an arts-informed lens is applicable to all elements of the work that you do. There is a way to explore how an arts-based understanding can be applied to the community and the way that we can collectively enable the establishment of a clear and engaging sense of identity, both within each district and ultimately for the broader Waikato.  In the earlier phases of the Waikato Arts Navigator, we completed some research in the community, examining strengths, capturing a picture of what exists and where the strengths are within your district. This work was originally developed in 2019. It provides a picture of where things sat pre-COVID and showed that there is an arts-aligned community within your district.  This is a community that can be supported and enabled to reach out more, to develop their own capability and to increase their engagement with the broader community. And these are some of the areas where the strengths lie.  In a recovery environment, there are going to be some issues, some challenges to address. Economic downturn, physical and mental health, and increasing inequality. But with this, there are also opportunities to see the call, to explore your own backyard, to buy local and to support local. And through arts activity, we can provide an extended process for that kind of engagement.  Arts can serve the community in a range of ways, and artists can be the first responders, and Creative Waikato is here to help. We have a pathway for you to work with us here around providing some strategic vision and project planning that can enable more of this work to happen within your community and by people in your district. The pathway, which is presented in more detail in the report, has us working together to explore opportunities and solutions, activating a process, and then collectively enjoying the outcomes.  The scope for this work is extremely flexible and scalable. It depends on the vision that you have, the scope of the outcomes you wish to enable, and the scale of the budget that can be applied to it. As part of this, we want to just take a little bit of time to outline some of the examples of this type of work that has happened elsewhere. And these are all examples that could definitely be made to happen within your part of the world. Des will talk a little bit about this.
speaker: jeremymayall

text: Kia ora koutou everyone. So the following few slides are just, as Jeremy has said, they are international and local examples of what can be done in a post-recovery environment. Now this particular example is the Yopishi Festival, which means let's do it in Japanese. So it was driven by a Japanese art collector who took a whole lot of artists back to her hometown in Ofunato, which is in the northeast of Japan.  So obviously it was devastated by the 2011 tsunami so she just wanted to look at art solutions as a way of bringing her community together. So this particular example is of a makeshift playground for children but they also had  Things like Dream Shopping Street where people could write handwritten notes and their dreams and wishes for the future. They could light lanterns, receive massages, listen to local stories and it was just a way of galvanising people together in quite a traumatic time.  This particular example is from Seattle. It's actually called Shun Pike. It invites a series of artists to show their works in empty storefronts. So it's a way of art really reaching out to passersby and bringing the community together as well. It encourages an arts ecology and also local entrepreneurship.
speaker: jeremymayall

text: This was a post-COVID initiative to encourage more activity in city centres.  There's also opportunity for performance festivals. This could be multiple bands. It could be single performers. It could be buskers. You will have seen some of this taking place in your district through the Best Fest initiative, which we ran a few weeks ago, which was throughout the Waikato region, which had performers performing in the streets just to inspire and encourage community well-being. This is from a festival in Wellington.  We have the opportunity to create works that take over public spaces and these could be pop-up installations that can be really community focused and participatory and there are a range of examples of this that happened in Christchurch post-earthquake as well.  This is from a group in Santa Fe, which is a group called Meow Wolf, and they do immersive art installations. They take over empty buildings and commission artists to create work that becomes an artwork that you can move about inside. It's a huge business for them in terms of economic development and tourism. And there is plenty of talented artists within the region who can do this type of work.  This is an image from the Boone Street Art Festival. The Boone Street Art Festival in Hamilton was initially kind of started in response to the CBD being empty because shops had moved out to the base at the north end of Hamilton.  and so it was a way of reinvigorating what was going on in the city and that festival's been running for five years has done a number of walls and has increased the kind of vibrancy within Hamilton and this is the type of work that can certainly happen anywhere and this is an image from an installation like the Meow Wolf work that occurred in an empty  building in the CBD in Hamilton as well. This was a kind of pathway through that had six different zones with six different artists creating work.  So the arts inspire, challenge, and expand our minds. They engage our creativity and allow us to experience the world through someone else's reality. From education to wellbeing, to quality of life, the arts are crucial to our success, health, and happiness. Each generation has its own unique set of challenges, but it is through the arts that we learn compassion, curiosity, understanding, and critical thinking skills that enable us to address problems and to find solutions.  Successful recovery is about defining clearly, focusing locally, spending social capital, and creating compelling narratives. It is first and foremost about people and places, not processes and policies. The arts can serve as an antidote to times of chaos. It can be a route to clarity, and it can be a force of resistance and repair, providing new registers, new languages in which to think.  the arts can be a catalyst to affect such change and through the Waikato Arts Navigator and the strategic support of Creative Waikato this can happen in your district as well. So we very much look forward to working with you to explore the possibilities of what arts can do in this time of recovery. Thank you.
speaker: jeremymayall

So look, lots of synergies, if you like, in terms of your thinking around place shaping and sense of  identity and self and the things that we are hoping as a community board to be able to facilitate the creation of and from a personal sense I've actually posted several posts on Facebook grapevine pages asking people what they feel is about looking at certain items and in particular the Jeremy's painting on wall mural on the side of the former or the museum there and people's response is nothing but positive and there is  there is nobody that finds, that I could elicit anyway, any negativity. text: Yeah, look, it's just a comment, just a clarification around the comments there by Jim and Liz around the school and the sort of in-zone, out-of-zone.  Schools are zoned and that school will be zoned. And so you can take as many out of zone children as you wish as a school. And through that, you generate two things. You generate additional staffing.  So it doesn't matter if the children are in zone or out of zone. You attract additional revenue with every child. So again, it doesn't matter if the child is in zone or out of zone. However, what you do not attract is extra building space that is only attracted through children that are in zone. So I guess what the ministry will be saying is  is as the subdivisions fill up, you will manage your out-of-zone children out and there will come a point where you probably are owed buildings potentially. But realistically, the data that would be important to know how far away that is, is how many out-of-zone enrolments that school has compared with in-zone enrolments. And that will give you  in terms of current numbers, how much space there would be. And then the ministry would also, along with the board of trustees, determine how big that site capacity actually is for children. So getting those sort of figures together, you could sort of start ballparking with the ministry predictions of what a house generates in terms of primary school children.  So there's a little bit to it, but it's not rocket science. There's just a little bit to it. It's just a few questions and a few formulas that one would need to go through to look at real capacity of in-zone students.
speaker: mikepettit

text: Yeah, thank you for that clarification, Mike. Good to have the understanding about that in-zone funding in terms of buildings. I wasn't aware of the distinction between the in-zone and out-of-zone, so thank you. Are there any other questions? Claire, I believe you have one.

It does concern me that we spent a lot of time in the regitry years ago, putting N1, N2, N3 at an area of what's 102 hectares, I think, if I'm correct.  keep Ngāina pre-development on one side of the road, not because it was foreseen across the other side, the sort of hapō side of the State Highway. So, we've kept it like that. There's going to be massive growth before 2050. That whole area could be filled up with houses. That's most probably the vision. So, we've got to get this right. The roundabout is most probably a good idea.  I don't think there's been any deaths now, but it's going to happen now. We've got two straight roads going straight through. So yeah, and one of my big regrets is that now the landowner has changed. We had quite a, it wasn't a complicated system to acquire a fair bit of that land at minimal cost to council. And I know the new landowner, from what I know of their business aspirations, I don't think that same deal would be on the table. So we're going to have to,  pay for it to achieve something that was achievable, you know, 10 years ago for minimal costs. But we've got to move on. I think whatever you may come up with, the entry landowners in the future, you have most probably a good idea if that road could be moved, but that's a major. I wish you good luck. And we have lost, from a historical point of view,  Mr Fox left the Prawnia Ward Committee because of the frustrations with how this progress was happening, especially in this little patch. Okay, I'm pleased that he's still running the community group because he's a good man to lead that. So I just hope this works out and there's been a lot of money spent on it. That's much to my detriment when I did bring it up that we started reinventing the wheel that a lot of this work had been done.  Yeah, I hope it does proceed, and I look forward to it if I live long enough. Thank you.

text: That moves us on then to our ninth item, the dog control on Mount Kakapuku matter. And I have in my list here that it should be Carl Tutte.  do we have Carl around or I have Sally Sheedy's name appearing very large on my screen so I'm not quite sure what's happening here we've got Carl here oh excellent fantastic Sally's gone that's great Carl welcome and take away thank you
speaker: susanoregan

text: Thank you, Madam Chair. Good morning, everybody. So this is an information-only report at this stage, just to make you aware of this item that is on the Iwi Consultative Committee's agenda for tomorrow, with the expectation that it is going to come back to this committee in due course for your consideration. So I'll take my report as read. The two main issues that have been raised are, firstly, concerns as to whether the controls that are currently applied to Mount Kakapuku are appropriate.  but probably more importantly, whether the process that led to those controls back in 2015, and if not before, were appropriate. So, staff have taken a considerable amount of time to look at the options in this space. We obviously have some sympathy for these issues that are being raised. It's not as straightforward as we would  have liked in terms of working towards a resolution. Because these controls are applied by the dog control policy, the only real option we can see at this stage is a review of that policy where those controls sit. And at this point in time, that's not scheduled until 2025.  So before we look at going down the track to review the policy, we just want to ensure that there's a consensus that this change is justified, but more importantly, that we've identified any other areas of concern that may have been missed previously as well. So that's the main reason why we're referring it to the  the Iwi Consultative Committee to not only look at kekapuku specifically and whether that is a trigger for a policy review, but also if there are other areas of concern where controls either aren't appropriate or aren't in place at all, so that we can weigh up the considerations there. Because we do, on the other hand, have  other things to consider in terms of Council's obligations under the Dog Control Act. And being mindful that if we go down the path of a full review, it will open the door to any other opinions that the public may wish to present through that process. So, as I said, the matter's on the agenda tomorrow with a recommendation that that committee report back with its views around Kickapooka in particular, around the timeframe for the review of the policy  and with details on any other areas that may need to be incorporated into that process. So that's the quick summary. I'm happy to take any questions.
